df-staf
blocks.content: Define the functionalization of the involution in a star ring. This is not strictly necessary but by having ` *r ` as an actual function we can state the principal properties of an involution much more cleanly. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)

blocks.name: df-srng
blocks.content: Define class of all star rings. A star ring is a ring with an involution (conjugation) function. Involution (unlike say the ring zero) is not unique and therefore must be added as a new component to the ring. For example, two possible involutions for complex numbers are the identity function and complex conjugation. Definition of involution in [Holland95] p. 204. (Contributed by NM, 22-Sep-2011.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)

  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c3))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(cstv, c3))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cstf, c3))
} = {
  syl6reqr(c2, c0, cmpt(hs0, c1, cfv(c0, cv(hs0))), wfn(c0, c1))
  biimpi(wfn(c0, c1), wceq(c0, cmpt(hs0, c1, cfv(c0, cv(hs0)))))
  dffn5(hs0, c0, c1)
  staffval(hs0, c2, c1, c0, c3)

  diff.hs0.c(c3)
}

blocks.name: srngrhm
blocks.content: The involution function in a star ring is an antiautomorphism. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)

blocks.name: srngring
blocks.content: A star ring is a ring. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)

blocks.name: srngcnv
blocks.content: The involution function in a star ring is its own inverse function. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)

blocks.name: srngf1o

blocks.content: The involution function in a star ring is closed in the ring. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm srngcl(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, csr), wcel(c1, c2)), wcel(cfv(c3, c1), c2))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cstv, c0))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
} = {
  eqeltrrd(cfv(c3, c1), c2, cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c1), wa(wcel(c0, csr), wcel(c1, c2)))
  adantl(wcel(c0, csr), wcel(c1, c2), wceq(cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c1), cfv(c3, c1)))
  stafval(c1, c2, cfv(cstf, c0), c3, c0)
  ffvelrnda(c1, c2, cfv(cstf, c0), c2, wcel(c0, csr))
  syl(wcel(c0, csr), wf(cfv(cstf, c0), c2, c2), wf1o(cfv(cstf, c0), c2, c2))
  srngf1o(c0, cfv(cstf, c0), c2)
  eqid(cfv(cstf, c0))
  f1of(cfv(cstf, c0), c2, c2)
}

thm srngnvl(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {

  fveq2d(cfv(cstf, c0), cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c1), cfv(c3, c1), wa(wcel(c0, csr), wcel(c1, c2)))
  adantl(wcel(c0, csr), wcel(c1, c2), wceq(cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c1), cfv(c3, c1)))

blocks.name: srng1
blocks.content: The conjugate of the ring identity is the identity. (This is sometimes taken as an axiom, and indeed the proof here follows because we defined ` *r ` to be a ring homomorphism, which preserves 1; nevertheless, it is redundant, as can be seen from the proof of ~ issrngd .) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Oct-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm srng1(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, csr), wceq(cfv(c1, c2), c2))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cstv, c0))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cur, c0))
} = {
  eqtr3d(cfv(c1, c2), c2, cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c2), wcel(c0, csr))
  3syl(wcel(c0, csr), wceq(cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c2), cfv(c1, c2)), wcel(c0, crg), wcel(c2, cfv(cbs, c0)))
  srngring(c0)
  ringidcl(c0, c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  stafval(c2, cfv(cbs, c0), cfv(cstf, c0), c1, c0)
  eqid(cfv(cbs, c0))
  syl(wcel(c0, csr), wceq(cfv(cfv(cstf, c0), c2), c2), wcel(cfv(cstf, c0), co(c0, crh, cfv(coppr, c0))))
  srngrhm(c0, cfv(cstf, c0), cfv(coppr, c0))
  eqid(cfv(cstf, c0))
  rhm1(cfv(cstf, c0), c0, cfv(coppr, c0), c2, c2)
  oppr1(c2, cfv(coppr, c0), c0)
  eqid(cfv(coppr, c0))
}

blocks.name: idsrngd
blocks.content: A commutative ring is a star ring when the conjugate operation is the identity. (Contributed by Thierry Arnoux, 19-Apr-2019.)
